title: What Medicines Were Used in the 1800s?
author: Medical Author Nazneen Memon; BHMS; PGDCR Medical Reviewer Shaziya Allarakha; MD
description: Medicine has changed significantly over the centuries. Here is a look back at common medicines used in the 1800s and remedies that are still used today.
cleaned_text: Medicine has changed significantly over the centuries. Remedies used in the 19th century included both quack potions to legitimate treatments, and some helped enlighten the field of science down to this day. Common medicines used in 1800s include: - Painkillers such as opium, morphine, phenacetin, and acetanilide - Antipyretics (medications for [fever](https://www.medicinenet.com/aches_pain_fever/article.htm)) such as willow bark and meadowsweet - Cathartics from various plants to accelerate defecation and as a cleanser of the lower gastrointestinal tract - Opium to combat [diarrhea](https://www.medicinenet.com/diarrhea/article.htm)and [cough](https://www.medicinenet.com/chronic_cough/article.htm) [Cocaine](https://www.medicinenet.com/cocaine_and_crack_abuse/article.htm)to relieve toothaches or oral pains - Camphor to soothe [itchy](https://www.medicinenet.com/itch/article.htm)skin [Arsenic](https://www.medicinenet.com/arsenic_poisoning/article.htm)and mercury to treat venereal diseases, primarily [syphilis](https://www.medicinenet.com/syphilis_in_women_overview/article.htm) - Disinfectants such as carbolic, chlorine, lime, charcoal, and sulfur - Alternative therapies such as massage, caustics, [blistering](https://www.medicinenet.com/blisters/symptoms.htm), warm baths, wraps, and gargles Dosage methods included powders, pills, tablets, gelatin capsules, pastilles, lozenges, mixtures, tinctures, and emulsions. Ointments, lotions and applied externally, whereas enemas, suppositories, pessaries, and inhalations were intended to be taken via a body orifice. What medical theory was followed in the 1800s? Many 19th century medicines and practices were based on a theory developed by the Roman physician Galen. According to this theory, the [human body](https://www.medicinenet.com/human_body_quiz/quiz.htm) is made up of four humors: blood, [phlegm](https://www.medicinenet.com/treating_congestion/article.htm), yellow bile, and black bile. The relative amounts and predominance of each humor in the body determine health, disease, and temperament in each individual: - Blood: Sanguine temperament - Phlegm: Phlegmatic temperament - bile: Choleric or bilious temperament - Black bile: Melancholic temperament What medical discoveries were made in the 1800s? Many medical devices can trace their origins to the 1800s, including: [Aspirin](https://www.medicinenet.com/acetylsalicylic_acid/article.htm) - Rene Laennec's Stethoscope - Ophthalmoscope - Quinine [malaria](https://www.medicinenet.com/malaria_facts/article.htm)treatment - Use of nitric oxide as an anesthetic - Antiseptic principle of surgery - First [vaccine](https://www.medicinenet.com/vaccination_faqs/article.htm)for [cholera](https://www.medicinenet.com/cholera/article.htm) - Use of [X-rays](https://www.medicinenet.com/x-rays/article.htm)to find bullets in the body - First [smallpox vaccine](https://www.medicinenet.com/smallpox/article.htm) - Discovery of germ theory (pasteurization and sterilization process) - Description of [leukemia](https://www.medicinenet.com/leukemia/article.htm)as a blood disorder - Akouphone, the world's first electric [hearing](https://www.medicinenet.com/deafness/article.htm)aid - Discovery of the fact that the [malaria](https://www.medicinenet.com/malaria_symptoms_and_signs/symptoms.htm)parasite was transmitted by mosquitoes - First successful human [blood transfusion](https://www.medicinenet.com/blood_transfusion/article.htm) - First open- [heart](https://www.medicinenet.com/heart_how_the_heart_works/article.htm)surgery performed [](https://www.medicinenet.com/causes_of_fatigue_pictures_slideshow/article.htm) SLIDESHOWSee Slideshow What older remedies are still used today? [Penicillin](https://www.medicinenet.com/penicillins-injection/article.htm): This revolutionary medicine originally discovered from the Penicillium [mold](https://www.medicinenet.com/mold_exposure/article.htm)that naturally produces penicillin. The drug grew in popularity at the end of the Second World War. - Sulfa or [sulfonamides](https://www.medicinenet.com/sulfonamides-oral/article.htm): This was the first compound shown to effectively treat infections that were introduced in 1935 by Gerhard Domagk. - Aspirin: Available since 1899, this was referred to as a "wonder drug" for its ability to be used for inflammation, [pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/pain_management/article.htm)relief, and as a blood thinning agent in blood clotting disorders such as [heart attacks](https://www.medicinenet.com/heart_attack/article.htm)or [blood clots](https://www.medicinenet.com/blood_clots/article.htm)in legs. [Insulin](https://www.medicinenet.com/insulin/drug-class.htm): Initially identified in 1869 and first used in humans in 1920 to treat [diabetes](https://www.medicinenet.com/diabetes_mellitus/article.htm), this medicine has greatly improved the quality of life for patients with [diabetes](https://www.medicinenet.com/type_2_diabetes_pictures_slideshow/article.htm)by slowing the progression of the disease on blood vessels and other organs. - Morphine: It was first marketed in 1827 to control [pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/pain_quiz/quiz.htm)and is derived from opium. It is known for its powerful analgesic effects. - Digitalis or [Digoxin](https://www.medicinenet.com/digoxin/article.htm): Derived from the foxglove plant, it has been used to treat [heart failure](https://www.medicinenet.com/heart_failure/article.htm), heart rhythm problems, and [pulmonary hypertension](https://www.medicinenet.com/pulmonary_hypertension/article.htm). [Nitroglycerin](https://www.medicinenet.com/nitroglycerin/article.htm): First used in 1867 to treat [angina](https://www.medicinenet.com/angina_symptoms/article.htm), this drug is very effective in relaxing veins and sometimes arteries to relieve [chest pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/chest_pain/article.htm). - Leeches: Since the early days of the Egyptians, this therapy has been used for more than 3,000 years to treat many nervous system abnormalities, enhance circulation, and promote [wound](https://www.medicinenet.com/cuts_scrapes_and_puncture_wounds/article.htm)healing. Common Medical Abbreviations & Terms Doctors, pharmacists, and other health-care professionals use abbreviations, acronyms, and other terminology for instructions and information in regard to a patient's health condition, prescription drugs they are to take, or medical procedures that have been ordered. There is no approved this list of common medical abbreviations, acronyms, and terminology used by doctors and other health- care professionals. You can use this list of medical abbreviations and acronyms written by our doctors the next time you can't understand what is on your prescription package, blood test results, or medical procedure orders. Examples include: - ANED: Alive no evidence of disease. The patient arrived in the ER alive with no evidence of disease. - ARF: Acute renal (kidney) failure - cap: Capsule. - CPAP: Continuous positive airway pressure. A treatment for sleep apnea. - DJD: Degenerative joint disease. Another term for osteoarthritis. - DM: Diabetes mellitus. Type 1 and type 2 diabetes - HA: Headache - IBD: Inflammatory bowel disease. A name for two disorders of the gastrointestinal (BI) tract, Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis - JT: Joint - N/V: Nausea or vomiting. - p.o.: By mouth. From the Latin terminology per os. - q.i.d.: Four times daily. As in taking a medicine four times daily. - RA: Rheumatoid arthritis - SOB: Shortness of breath. - T: Temperature. Temperature is recorded as part of the physical examination. It is one of the "vital signs." Keep Your Medicines StraightGet tips from WebMD on keeping tracking of when and how to take your medications. Laryngitis Home RemediesLaryngitis is an inflammation of the larynx. Inflammation of the larynx is most often caused by viral infections. Symptoms include sore throat, cough, problems swallowing, and fever. The voice changes produced by laryngitis may last after the fever and other symptoms of the acute infection have gone away. The best natural home remedy to relieve pain and other symptoms caused by laryngitis includes resting your voice and breathing humidified air often. Turning on the hot water in the bathroom and then sitting in the steam can soothe and relieve laryngitis symptoms. Acetaminophen (Tylenol) and anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen Aleve) can relieve pain and inflammation caused by laryngitis. Don't give children aspirin to infants, toddlers, children, and teens because of the risk of developing Reye's syndrome, which can be fatal. Home remedies like resting your voice and sitting in humidified air can cure laryngitis. Medications like ibuprofen (Advil, Aleve) and acetaminophen (Tylenol) can relieve and soothe pain and symptoms caused by laryngitis.
